answer_html: Hence the domain of \(g(x)\) is \(\{x \mathbb{R} \mid x\geq 1 \}\) or \(x \in [1,\infty)\).
answer_latex:
Hence the domain of $g(x)$ is $\{x \mathbb{R} \mid x\geq 1 \}$ or
$x \in [1,\infty)$.
hints_html:
Recall that from part (a), we have that

\(\displaystyle (f \circ f)(x) = \sqrt{\sqrt{x}-1} -1\)

when dealing with square roots, what problems could arise? The domain of this function should avoid these problems.
hints_latex:
Recall that from
{part
(a)}, we have that

$\displaystyle (f \circ f)(x) = \sqrt{\sqrt{x}-1} -1$

when dealing with square roots, what problems could arise? The domain of
this function should avoid these problems.
hints_raw:
Recall that from [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH110/December_2013/Question_04_(a)|part (a)]], we have that 

<math> \displaystyle (f \circ f)(x) = \sqrt{\sqrt{x}-1} -1</math>

when dealing with square roots, what problems could arise? The domain of this function should avoid these problems.
question: 4 (b)
sols_html:
Looking at the outside function, we want to find \(\sqrt{x}-1\geq 0\) for \(\sqrt{\sqrt{x}-1}\) to be defined.

So we want \(\sqrt{x} \geq 1\). Looking at the inside function, we want \(\sqrt{x} \geq 0\) so \(x \geq 0\).

Combining the two, we get

\[\begin{aligned} x\geq 0\end{aligned}\]

and \(x\geq 1\).

Hence the domain of \(g(x)\) is \(\{x \mathbb{R} \mid x\geq 1 \}\) or \(x \in [1,\infty)\).
sols_latex:
Looking at the outside function, we want to find $\sqrt{x}-1\geq 0$ for
$\sqrt{\sqrt{x}-1}$ to be defined.

So we want $\sqrt{x} \geq 1$. Looking at the inside function, we want
$\sqrt{x} \geq 0$ so $x \geq 0$.

Combining the two, we get\begin{align*}
x\geq 0
\end{align*} and $x\geq 1$.

Hence the domain of $g(x)$ is $\{x \mathbb{R} \mid x\geq 1 \}$ or
$x \in [1,\infty)$.
sols_raw:
Looking at the outside function, we want to find <math>\sqrt{x}-1\geq 0</math> for <math>\sqrt{\sqrt{x}-1}</math> to be defined.

So we want <math>\sqrt{x} \geq 1</math>. Looking at the inside function, we want <math>\sqrt{x} \geq 0</math> so <math>x \geq 0</math>.

Combining the two, we get:<math>x\geq 0</math> and <math>x\geq 1</math>.

Hence the domain of <math>g(x)</math> is <math>\{x \mathbb{R} \mid x\geq 1 \}</math> or <math>x \in [1,\infty)</math>.
statement_html: Let \(f(x)=\sqrt{x}-1\) and \(g(x)=(f\circ f)(x)\). What is the domain of \(g(x)\)?
statement_latex:
Let $f(x)=\sqrt{x}-1$ and $g(x)=(f\circ f)(x)$. What is the domain of
$g(x)$?
statement_raw: Let <math>f(x)=\sqrt{x}-1</math> and <math>g(x)=(f\circ f)(x)</math>. What is the domain of <math>g(x)</math>?
